'''John Wesley Funchess''' (April 16, 1931 – February 1, 1994)<ref name="Dead">[http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/1995.html Thedeadrockstarsclub.com] - accessed May 2010</ref> known professionally as '''John (or Johnny) Littlejohn''', was an [[United States|American]] [[electric blues]] [[slide guitar]]ist.<ref name="Music">{{cite book
| first= Paul
| last= Du Noyer
| year= 2003
| title= The Illustrated Encyclopedia of Music
| edition= 1st
| publisher= Flame Tree Publishing 
| location= Fulham, London
| isbn= 1-904041-96-5
| page= 181}}</ref> He was active on the [[Chicago blues]] circuit from the 1950s to the 1980s.<ref name="Music"/>

==Biography==
Born in [[Lake, Mississippi|Lake]], [[Mississippi]], [[United States]], Littlejohn first learned to play the blues from Henry Martin, a friend of his father. In 1946 he left home and traveled widely, spending time in [[Jackson, Mississippi|Jackson]], [[Mississippi]], [[Arkansas]], [[Rochester, New York|Rochester]], [[New York]], and [[Gary, Indiana|Gary]], [[Indiana]].<ref name="AMG">{{cite web |first= |last= |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p18539/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Biography by Bill Dahl |publisher=Allmusic.com |accessdate=September 3, 2011}}</ref> He settled in the last of these in 1951, playing whenever possible in the Chicago area.  Through his connections on the Gary, music scene he was acquainted with Joe Jackson, patriarch of the musical Jackson family, and Littlejohn and his band reputedly served as an occasional rehearsal band for the [[Jackson 5]] in the mid to late 1960s.

Littlejohn played regularly in Chicago clubs (he was filmed by drummer [[Sam Lay]] playing with [[Howlin' Wolf]]'s band c. 1961) but did not make any [[recording studio|studio]] [[sound recording and reproduction|recordings]] until 1968, when he cut [[single (music)|singles]] for several [[record label]]s.<ref name="AMG"/> Later that year he recorded an [[album]] with [[Arhoolie Records]], and four songs for [[Chess Records]], though the Chess tracks were not issued at the time.<ref name="AMG"/>

Although he recorded a few singles for small local labels, Littlejohn did not record another album until 1985, when [[Rooster Blues]] issued ''So-Called Friends''. Soon after, he fell into ill health, and died of [[renal failure]] in Chicago 1994, at the age of 62.<ref name="Dead"/><ref name="AMG"/>

==Discography==
{{Expand list|date=October 2009}}

*''Dream'' ([[Storyville Records]], 1995; recorded live 1976)
*''John Littlejohn's Blues Party'' ([[Wolf Records]])
